note.p: Joseph Emerson Brown was governor of Georgia during the Civil War.

Born on April 15, 1821, in Pickens County, South Carolina, Brown moved as a child with his family to Union County, Georgia. As a young man, he became a teacher and private tutor, and then attended Yale University to study law. He started a very successful law firm in Canton, Georgia, in 1847, accumulating wealth and prestige within the state. In 1849 he was elected to the Georgia Senate and then secured a seat as a state circuit court judge in 1855.

Brown won the 1857 gubernatorial election in Georgia, becoming governor at the age of 36. He championed public education and railroad development, appointing a savvy businessman he knew from Canton to supervise the state-owned railroad. The effort succeeded, and within three years the Western and Atlantic Railroad went from nearly bankruptcy to a financial profitable institution.

Brown won reelection as governor in 1859 and was in office during the contentious presidential election of 1860. He was a Democrat and slave owner, registering nineteen enslaved African Americans in his household in 1860, and strongly supported secession when the anti-slavery Republican candidate Abraham Lincoln won. Brown was one of the south’s leading advocates for state autonomy over federal authority. This state’s rights advocacy put him into conflict with Confederate officials during the subsequent Civil War, as Brown became a leading critic of Confederate president Jefferson Davis and policies that strengthened the government in Richmond and weakened Georgia’s military and political interests. He specifically condemned Confederate laws that allowed confiscation of goods and the impressment of slaves for Confederate labor projects. His opposition to Davis likely inspired officials in Richmond and in other southern states to oppose the Confederate government on key issues, weakening the south’s war effort.

Brown called for an end of the Civil War in late 1864, after William Tecumseh Sherman’s Union forces captured Atlanta, Georgia, and marched across the state to capture Savannah. He ordered the Georgia militia to withdraw from the military front and assist in growing crops to start rebuilding the state’s infrastructure. When the war ended in 1865, Brown was arrested by federal officials and spent several weeks imprisoned in Washington, D.C.

Upon his release from prison, Brown switched his political alliances from the Democratic Party to the Republican Party. He supported President Andrew Johnson’s lenient Reconstruction policies, served as a delegate to the 1868 Republican National Convention, and even scored an appointment as a Republican to serve as chief justice of Georgia’s Supreme Court from 1868 to 1870.

Brown left the Supreme Court to be president of the Western and Atlantic Railroad. His work there, as well as other business dealings, helped him accrue a personal wealth of over one million dollars by 1880 (nearly three million dollars in modern figures). When Reconstruction ended in 1877, he reestablished himself within the Democratic Party, winning election for the U.S. Senate from Georgia. He remained in that seat until 1891, when he retired due to health concerns. He passed away on November 30, 1894, at the age of 73. Brown was married to Elizabeth Grisham and had at least eight children. Brown is buried in Oakland Cemetery in Atlanta, Georgia.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; New Georgia Encyclopedia)

note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)

note.p: John Jones (nicknamed "Honest Jack") was born on July 3, 1814, in Baldwin County, Georgia. He served in both the Indian and Mexican Wars as a captain. On June 21, 1850, Jones married Susan C. Williams in Baldwin County, Georgia. The couple had no children.

By at least 1860, Jones was serving as Georgia’s state treasurer, and he was re-elected in 1861. At the outbreak of the Civil War, he organized a company of soldiers but was instead elected to continue as state treasurer, a position he held throughout the war.

During Reconstruction, Jones remained in office as treasurer. Working with Governor Charles J. Jenkins during federal military occupation, he helped hide approximately $400,000 in state funds to prevent their seizure. Under Governor James M. Smith’s administration, an additional $880,000 was reported missing, creating a total deficit of over $1,280,000, though the funds were later accounted for and returned. Democrats celebrates Jones for his role in preventing federal accounting of the monies. By 1869, Jones was listed as a former treasurer in the Georgia Journal and Messenger, indicating he had left office. However, he was re-elected as state treasurer on January 11, 1873, returning to his post.
John Jones passed away on February 28, 1893, in Milledgeville, Georgia. He was buried in Memory Hill Cemetery.

(The Atlanta Journal, February 28, 1893; FindaGrave; The Macon Telegraph, December 1, 1861; Georgia Journal and Messenger, February 23, 1869; Georgia Weekly Telegraph, Journal and Messenger, September 19, 1876)

Located in central Georgia, Jasper County was founded under the name Randolph County on December 10, 1807 from Baldwin County and was renamed Jasper County on December 10, 1812. (New Georgia Encyclopedia; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Baldwin County, Milledgeville was founded in 1804 and serves as the county seat. Milledgeville served as the capital of Georgia from 1804 until 1868. (New Georgia Encyclopedia)

gloss.p: Engaging in "illegal activities." (Cambridge Dictionary)
The criminal act defined as "a sudden, violent attack on someone" or "the crime of attacking and beating someone." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The crime of intentionally killing a person." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The decision of a court that someone is not guilty." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of formally accusing someone of a serious crime." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"An officer who is responsible for the money in a company, government, or other organization." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A public officer who judges local and less important legal cases, and performs marriage ceremonies." (Cambridge Dictionary)

“Someone who works in an office, writing letters, making phone calls, and arranging meetings for a person or for an organization.” (Cambridge Dictionary) CWRGM includes people who perform administrative assistance under this tag, but we do not include government positions that incorporate the word secretary, such as Secretary of State, under this subject tag.
"A place where trials and other legal cases happen, or the people present in such a place." (Cambridge Dictionary)

Operating at the state level, the Executive Department of State of Georgia was established in the Georgia Constitution of 1777. The department is headed by the Governor who is the head of the state government. The Governor is elected to a four-year term and is limited to two terms by the Georgia Constitution of 1983. To qualify for office, candidates must be at least 35 years of age, a United States citizen for at least 15 years, and a resident of Georgia for 15 years. (New Georgia Encyclopedia; Britannica; Wikipedia)

gloss.p: Operating at the state level, the Office of the Secretary of State of Georgia was established in 1777. It is an office within the Executive Department and headed by the Secretary of State. The Secretary is responsible for keeping the state seal and flag, overseeing statewide elections, and managing public records. Until 1880 the Secretary was elected by the State Legislature but is now publicly elected and their term in office is four years. (New Georgia Encyclopedia; Wikipedia)

The term "fugitive from justice" is defined broadly and covers a multiplicity of experiences under U.S. law, but refers most often to "a person who is fleeing from custody, whether it be from jail, a government arrest, government or non-government questioning, vigilante violence, or outraged private individuals" (Wikipedia). Slightly different than the above definition, a fugitive from justice may also be defined as "a person formally charged with a crime or a convicted criminal whose punishment has not yet been determined or fully served who is currently beyond the custody or control" of the party, be it local, national, or international, interested in their arrest (Wikipedia). In the nineteenth-century United States, fugitive status varied widely based on race. Many white people considered "fugitives from justice" were most often the latter definition, being those charged with or convicted of crimes who then fled across other state lines to try and evade punishment or trial. However, throughout American history up to Emancipation, fugitive status was given to escaped enslaved African Americans under the Fugitive Slave Laws of 1793 and later 1850. These laws also required anyone in the nation to apprehend self-emancipated enslaved people and return them to their owners. The term "fugitives from justice" therefore became another legal mechanism by which enslavers sought to control the movements and freedoms of the enslaved, while contributing heavily to the increasing sectionalism that would lead to the American Civil War (Britannica). To learn more about enslaved people who emancipations themselves and were labeled fugitives, see the "Emancipation and self-emancipation" subject tag under Events.
While the Cambridge Dictionary defines death as “the end of life,” CWRGM employs this subject tag to refer to human deaths only, both actual and hypothetical. (Cambridge Dictionary)

The nation experienced mass loss of life (approximately 2% of the population) during the American Civil War, which changed the way Americans viewed death and resulted in its reconceptualization in highly bureaucratized ways. Often wartime dead were buried without their names and sometimes in poorly-dug graves, which created a powerful, profound social and cultural dislocation for their surviving loved ones. During the 19th century, Americans understood dying as a social and religious experience, and desired a "good death," which they defined as at home surrounded by family, but these ideals were unattainable in war. Consequently, Americans learned to cope with death and memorialize it in new ways. Unionists encouraged the federal government and ex-Confederates pushed their respective state governments to create and fund national cemeteries, rebury deceases soldiers and veterans, and establish veterans' and widows' pensions. These new responses to death were more bureaucratized, nationalistic, and secularized. Wartime and post-war death was also highly impacted by race, as white supremacists desecrated the graves of Union buried in the South, especially the bodies of African Americans who served in U.S. Colored Troops and the white officers that led them, revealing post-war sectionalism and strains on reconciliation. (Drew Gilpin Faust, This Republic of Suffering)

Medical treatment of wounds and injuries during the nineteenth century was fairly primitive, and not substantially different than medical practices over the preceding few centuries. Doctors had little knowledge of bacteria, and therefore did not understand the importance of washing hands or sterilizing medical instruments when treating open wounds. Physicians learned that some substances seemed to aid recovery, such as iodine and bromine, but their properties were more mystery than scientifically understood. Additionally, antibiotics had not yet been discovered. As a result, even minor cuts could become infected and lead to severe disability or death.

During the Civil War, more than 475,000 soldiers were wounded in battle. Thousands more suffered injuries in camp or on the march. Medical care for wounded and injured soldiers typically involved closing wounds and setting broken bones. After suturing or bandaging these injuries, physicians would carefully observe their patients and try to offer some medical support, but recovery most often depended upon the wounded man’s natural healing. Some medical practices had unintended consequences, both positive and negative. Horsehair proved to be a popular material for sutures, due to its length and strength. To improve its elasticity, Civil War doctors boiled the horsehair, thereby disinfecting it. Wounds stitched closed with boiled horsehair were less likely to grow infected from the sutures, although this benefit was not fully understood until after the war. On the other hand, physicians probing for bullets or foreign objects inside a wound often introduced more bacteria and generated worse infections than the patient may have experienced without the procedure. This practice continued well after the Civil War, and likely contributed to President James Garfield’s death in 1881, when doctors repeatedly used unsterilized fingers and instruments while searching for the assassin’s bullet lodged in his body.

Doctors understood the danger of blood loss to wounded men, but devices such as the Petit Tourniquet—a French screw-tightened tourniquet designed in 1718—were typically found at a surgeon’s tent rather than with the soldiers along the front lines. Some physicians recommended supplying tourniquets among the soldiers, but others suggested much simpler practices, such as each soldier carrying a handkerchief or cloth strip and a six-inch long piece of wood in his pocket to function as a makeshift tourniquet. These life-saving practices were not mandated among Union and Confederate armies, though, and many wounded men died of blood loss before reaching medical help.

The most iconic treatment of battlefield wounds during the Civil War was amputation. Most casualties during the war were caused by musket fire. The large caliber lead balls often shattered bones upon impact. Unable to splint or repair bones so damaged, physicians frequently chose to amputate the wounded person’s limb above the injury. Doctors typically sewed a flap of skin over the stump. Unfortunately, due to the high incidents of infection for reasons described above, amputated limbs often became infected. Gangrene was among the most dangerous conditions, which could lead to death. The only method of combatting gangrene was to perform another amputation further up the limb (if possible) and hope it healed properly. Confederate and Union physicians performed around 50,000 amputations during the Civil War. Contrary to some popular myths, anesthesia, such as chloroform and ether, was in use during the Civil War, and around 95% of wounded soldiers were afforded some comfort before amputation.

Hundreds of thousands of soldiers returned home from the Civil War with scars or permanent disabilities from wartime wounds and injuries. The large number of amputees also led to new developments in prosthetics. Lessons learned from the war improved medical care a bit, as Union and Confederate doctors recorded their observations of wounds and treatments. Published reports provided a new wealth of information. However, only after scientists better understood microbes and accepted the Germ Theory in the late nineteenth and early twentieth century did medical practice substantially improve from the Civil War era practices. (Frank R. Freemon, Gangrene and Glory: Medical Care during the American Civil War, 41–50; Terry Reimer, “Wounds, Ammunition, and Amputation,” National Museum of Civil War Medicine; Paige Gibbons Backus, “Amputation and the Civil War,” American Battlefield Trust)

div.p: [seal]

STATE OF GEORGIA.
[seal] JOSEPH E. BROWN, Governor of said State.
To His Excellency the Governor of State of Mississippi:

IT APPEARS, by the annexed papers, duly authenticated according to the laws of this State, that on the twenty sixth day of October in the year Eighteen hundred and fifty six, in the county of Jasper in the state of Georgia Thomas Garnett and Jefferson Garnett committed the crime of Murder upon the body of Jordan Pye—
And it has been represented to me that said Jefferson Garnett has—fled from the justice of this State, and has taken refuge within the State, of Mississippi—

NOW, THEREFORE, pursuant to the provisions of the Constitution and Laws of the United States, in such case made and previded, I do hereby request that the said Jefferson Garnett—be delivered to Edward H. Pye and James O. Lane, or either of them who is duly authorized to receive and convey him to the State of Georgia, to be dealt with according to law.
[seal] EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT GEORGIA [/seal]

GIVEN under my Hand, and the Seal of the Executive Department at the Capitol in the City of Milledgeville, the 27th day of June in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and fiftySixty, and of the Independence of the United States of America the eighty fourth.

Joseph E Brown
BY THE GOVERNOR.
H, H, Waters.
Secretary Executive Department.

Recd two dollars & a half
Jno. Jones
Tr.

Entered
P Theatt,
Compt. Genl,

div.p: [seal]

Georgia
Jasper County

Personally came before me John F. Patterson a justice of the peace in and for said County Edward H. Pye who after being Sworn deposeth and says that in the County aforesaid on the twenty sixth day of October in the year eighteen hundred and fifty six one Thomas Garnett and Jefferson Garnett in and upon one Jordan Pye in the peace of God and said state then and there being did unlawfully will-fully feloniously and of their malice of aforethought did make an assault and with clubs, bottles, sticks, and rails him the said Jordan Pye did strike and beat giving to him divers wounds in and upon the head and body, of which Said mortal wounds as the said Jordan Pye in the County aforesaid on the twenty sixth day of October in the year eighteen hundred and fifty six died—And deponenth further saith that they the said Thomas Garnett and Jefferson Garnett did then

and there in manner and form aforesaid Commit the crime of murder—and that one Thomas C. Garnett was then and there present aiding and abetting the fact to be done as principal in the second degree—And deponenth further says that an Indictment has been found in Jasper Superior Court at the October Term eighteen hundred and fifty six against said Thomas Garnett and Jefferson Garnett for the crime of Murder and against Thomas C, Garnett as principal in the second degree in said Murder of upon which charge the said Thomas C. Garnett has been tried and acquitted, and that said Indict-ment is still pending against said Thomas Garnett and Jefferson Garnett=Deponent further says that said Indictment he is informed and believes is lost or mislaid—and that he makes this affida-vit—for the purpose of asking a requisition to be made by His Excellency

Joseph E. Brown Governor of said state of Georgia upon the Governor of the State of Mississippi for the arrest of said Jefferson and Thomas Garnett who he is informed and believes is a citizen of the State Mississippi—and asks that Deponent and James O. Lane may be appointed Agents to go after and bring said Jefferson Garnett ^Thomas Garnett^ to the State of Georgia—
Sworn to and subscribed before me this June 26th 1860
E H, Pye [?]
Jno. F. Patterson J. D.
[seal]

STATE OF GEORGIA.
BY HIS EXCELLENCY, JOSEPH E. BROWN, GOVERNOR OF SAID STATE.
To all to whom these Presents shall come:

KNOW YE THAT John F. Patterson—whose official signature appears to the within instrument, was, at the time affixing the same thereto, a duly commissioned and qualified Justice of the Peace in & for the county of Jasper—which appears from the records of file in this office—and that the same is in due form of law: Therefore, all due faith, credit and authority are and ought to be had and given to his said attestation as such.
IN TESTIMONY WHEREOF, I have hereunto set my hand, and caused the Great Seal of the State to be put and affixed.
DONE at the Capitol in Milledgeville, this 27th—day of June—in the year of our Lord eighteen hundred and fiftysixty and of the Independence of the United States of America the eighty fourth
[seal]EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT GEORGIA[seal]

Joseph E Brown
BY THE GOVERNOR
E. A. Watkins
SECRETARY OF STATE.

EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT, GEORGIA,
MILLEDGEVILLE, June 27th 18560
Registered & recd fee 25 cts

H. H, Waters.
Secretary Executive Department.
